messages.message:
RE: Human Review functionality:

When actively reviewing documents in the review modal, we have two "terminal" review actions available:
1. Mark as reviewed
2. Save and submit
First point of feedback:
1. I feel like `1.` and `2.` above are essentially the same? 
    a. `2. Save and submit` should be a button that only allows you to `submit` and requires you to `mark as reviewed` in order to submit.
        i. Ie. `Save and submit` -> `Submit` (contingent on marking as reviewed)
2. Connecting with `1.` immediately above, I feel like adding a third action, `skip` or `next` (and even `previous`, for that matter) would be good to have.
3. It may be nice to be able to add quick tags or notes to a document during review: 
    a. Should additional context be helpful when escalating or skipping a document, the escalating/skipping reviewer can provide such context and it would be made available to the next reviewer.
Back in the day, I've spent some time as an annotator/reviewer, and I've often found myself (and others, too) skipping/hitting `next` on items to address them later without escalating. We were also able to add notes for additional context, which was helpful at all levels of the review cycle and even helpful for improving solutions to be less confusing/more effective.

Happy to provide more detail as needed :sparkles:
thanks for sharing this! This is definitely top of mind, we're exploring how we can make that entire interaction far clearer in https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-3112. cc @Natasha as well
So nice to have people at instabase actively use human review and give feedback often :muscle::skin-tone-4:
I don't think we've explored a 'skip' action, but that is interesting. We were looking at progress bars within that experience to indicate how many reviews the user has left in their queue.
Currently the closest thing to skip is hotkeys for going to next doc

RE: Skip action:

With the `skip` button, I imagine that if I was in a review pool with other folks, I could be able to eventually get those `skipped` documents, and they might have a `skipped` tag applied, which could highlight to me that there was something potentially tricky to watch for.

And perhaps with enough skips, either by suggestion (pop-up modal?) or automation, the document gets submitted to the escalation queue :thought_balloon:
ohh i understand, skip entirely, not just within that review session

Hannah had some feedback around this stuff yesterday too having to do with the actions you can take from within human review (Udit you and I were talking about this) - if you’re just reviewing a single run you’ve been directly linked to, after you mark documents as reviews there’s no other action you can take to indicate you’re done.
